captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

I would like to speak of one
particular attitude and

practice we need to adopt if
we're to meet our Heavenly
Father's high expectations.

It is this: willingly to
accept and even seek
corrections.

Elder Hugh B. Brown told of
purchasing a rundown farm in
Canada many years ago.

As he went about cleaning up and
repairing his property, he

came across a currant bush that
had grown over six feet

high and was yielding
no berries.

So he pruned it back
drastically, leaving only
small stumps.

Then he saw a drop like a tear
on the top of each of these

little stumps, as if the currant
bush were crying, and

thought he heard it say: "How
could you do this to me?

I was making such wonderful
growth. ...
And now you've cut me down.

Every plant in the garden will
look down on me. ...
How could you do this to me?

I thought you were the
gardener here."

"Look, little currant bush, I
am the gardener here, and I
know what I want you to be.
I [don't]

intend you to be a fruit
tree or a shade tree.

I want you to be a currant
bush, and someday, little

currant bush, when you are
laden with fruit, you are

going to say, 'Thank you, Mr.
Gardener, for loving me enough
to cut me down.'"

Years later, Elder Brown
was in line to
be promoted to general.

But even though he was fully
qualified for the promotion,

it was denied him because
he was a Mormon.

Continuing his story, Elder
Brown remembered: "I got on

the train and started back ...
with a broken heart, with
bitterness in my soul. ...
When I got to my tent, ...
I threw my cap on the cot.

I clenched my fists, and
I shook them at heaven.

I said, 'How could you
do this to me, God?

I have done everything I could
to measure up. ...

How could you do this to me?'
And then I heard a voice. ...

It was my own voice, and
the voice said, 'I am
the gardener here.

I know what I want you to do.'
The bitterness went out of my

soul, and I fell on my knees by
the cot to ask forgiveness
for my ungratefulness. ...

And now, almost 50 years later,
I look up to [God]

and say, 'Thank you, Mr.
Gardener, for cutting me down,

for loving me enough to hurt
me.'" All of us can meet God's

high expectations, however great
or small our capacity
and talent may be.

Let us pray for His
love-inspired correction, in
the name of Jesus Christ, amen.

comments.text:
I have always loved this talk that Elder D. Todd Christofferson spoke. If 
we all look at the Lord's perspective, we will better understand what the 
Lord's plan for each of us is.﻿

comments.author: Sol Mar -Lo

comments.text:
There are so many times when I asked "Why me?” Even though I am only 18, I 
have gone through so much. Some people ask me how did you go through all 
that? Just faith in God that Everything will be okay, and the strength he 
gives me to keep going. So many times I have felt to give up, when 
everything around me have to crumble into pieces. I got addicted to self 
harm, cutting. But I know that I am grateful for the trials that have come 
into my life. That doesn't mean I want them to happen again. But that I 
have learned so much from all the mistakes I have made, the mistake of 
others. And losing people so close, knowing I'll see them again. He gives 
me the strength I need. I just need to do my part, and I know I'll overcome 
anything, even my addiction to cutting. And I leave this with you all..﻿
comments.author: Twistaa Yoshii

comments.text:
I'am very sorry that you are passing thru such feelings
families really are to be support for use
The world around us is very depressing if any one has any heart at all they 
will be troubled and saddened by the way we treat each other
I have had a hard time with it thru my life 
I hope I always will
it means I'am alive and I care
The drugs that man has made for things really hasn't help people
I have had many friends and Family that are now drug addicts, they just 
can't see it
Because doctors say it good for you
But it really isn't
These things you feel are difficult 
I admire those who see it and fight to get thru it
yes it will pass
But going thru a thing and looking back on a thing are two different 
animals altogether
We really do have a Loving Father who live in heaven
He does care
maybe it's hard to see it 
I know I don't understand why things happen
after I can see the wisdom
I think most of us will some day
Take care
and there are people who care
C.E. Mason

faith and keep up good courage and I should come out on the top of the 
heap.” - Joseph Smith

comments.text:
in times when we don't understand why something had to happen the way it 
did, this video and message is such a great resource and also remembering 
Christ's words when he said  "If the bitter cup does not pass, drink it and 
be strong, trusting in happier days ahead." There were many times when 
Christ wanted to question why poor things struck him, but know this brother 
and sisters, if you're on the path of God's will, nothing happens to you by 
accident. There is always a larger and bigger purpose God has for us that 
we may be a bit blind to in that moment. In those times, just be trusting 
in Him, and see for yourself what the outcome is :) I love you all.﻿

comments.author: Lina C

comments.text:
Earlier in October my brother tore his ACL in a football game. Playing 
football has been his dream and now it seems to be somewhat crushed. This 
has brought about a major change in the way my family functions. He just 
had surgery and is basically on bed rest. He can move with crutches 
occasionally but not often. His injury has taught me a great lesson- 
sometimes God gives us trials that seem to be cutting us down but are 
really, in the long run, going to build us up to be stronger. His attitude 
has changed since the accident and he has become a better brother. I'm so 
grateful for this experience and what has taught my brother and myself.
It reminded me of this video.﻿

always guide us to where we need to actually be.﻿

comments.author: Chuck Dean

comments.text:
When I was 15, I had great plans when I grew up, getting married, have 
childrens, live in a house designed by myself, have the ideal job, etc, but 
as the years went by,despite my efforts to make that happen, I realized 
that an invisible force was guiding me, whether I liked it, or not, and no 
matter how hard I was trying to make that happen, the path was already in 
front of me all along. Things did not turn out the way I wanted, but like 
an invisible hand that guides me, I somehow, find myself in the right place 
everytime.God knows what I need, and whats best for me, way before I even 
ask him, and when the time is right, just like the bush, I will thank him 
for cutting me down, for loving me enough to hurt me.I am doing exactly 
what he wanted from me, from the very beginning, no questions asked. What 
can I ask more, from the one that is giving me the world,every heartbeat, 
every tear, every thought,all that I experience, this is God.I live through 
him,﻿
comments.author: Elviro Mori

comments.author: Resty Macalisang

comments.text:
This morning, as I watched this video and listened to what the good Elder 
was telling me, I thought back to that day in the doctor's office when I 
was told my condition at that time would be the best I would ever be again. 
I could not walk. I could not use my hands to write anything. I could not 
speak very well. I was a total mess. 

I went home and turned my music up loud, then proceeded to have a temper 
tantrum,. I yelled at God and asked him why I could never be happy. I 
complained that I had never found happiness for longer than a year at a 
time, then all was misery. By the time my tantrum was over I was exhausted 
and fell into a sleep. 

Now, 14 years later, and many blessing from my beloved brethren later I can 
see that was only the beginning of my healing.I have bounced between 
illness and health. Between understanding and confusion. True, I still have 
a speech problem, and I am still having to use a wheel chair. However, I am 
happy to know that Father is pleased with what I am doing. He has joy when 
I repent and be myself. I know that God lives. I know that He loves me, and 
I also know that He loves you. 

Jesus is the Christ. He died that we can live. He set the perfect example 
of obedience and did it for you and me. I know that all will be well, no 
matter what happens because God is just. It took me a long time to 
understand that. But it is truth. I am so grateful for truth. 

I hope you will watch that video. ﻿
comments.author: Midge Taylor

comments.text:
Not if it's God who does the pruning. This video does not promote child 
abuse in any way. Never once does it mention or advocate hurting children. 
The point of the story is that we all go through trials and struggles, some 
of which can be painful. We can wallow in our hurt and anger, or we can 
have faith and learn from our experiences, and trust God.

comments.text:
We all go through trials in order to gain vital characteristics that are of 
Eternal weight in gold. When we cry about the horrible things that happen 
we should remember that God knows the glory that should follow after this 
life if we remain faithful. Much like when we see a child cry about having 
to wait for something, we the adult have a larger perspective. This is 
similar to what God sees. Not to mention the hurt spoken of in this video 
is specifically for what Elder Brown became.

comments.author: Mormon Channel

comments.text:
It isn't cutting down and hurting. It's pruning and correcting. There's a 
drastic difference. Mormons are the last people to promote child abuse. 
What is being said here is that loving parents must sometimes do things 
that children think are mean, but in reality are just the opposite. It may 
take time and perspective, but hopefully the child will recognize those 
loving acts for what they really are.
comments.author: 9Kita1
